guide.conclusion:
I hope this guide has been useful. Feel free to contact me with questions. I can be emailed at ObjectsUnlimited (at) Gmail (dot) com or via twitter @Protobotind .

Thanks!

flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
In order to complete this you must have downloaded and installed the free SketchUp program from Google as well as this free .STL and .DXF exporter. You must also download Pepakura3.

This guide shows you how to take a simple drawing that you have created or found and make it into a paper pattern. The creative individual can also export to a vinyl cutter or various types of CNC machines.
guide.introduction_rendered:
In order to complete this you must have downloaded and installed the free SketchUp program from Google as well as this free .STL and .DXF exporter. You must also download Pepakura3.

This guide shows you how to take a simple drawing that you have created or found and make it into a paper pattern. The creative individual can also export to a vinyl cutter or various types of CNC machines.

Tools
  • Computer running Windows XP, Vista, or Mac OS X
  • Glue or Tape
  • Printer
  • Scissors
  • internet

lines.text: After SketchUp, the .STL exporter and Pepakura have been installed it is time to try a simple model. I went to http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/ and chose "Geodesic dome 01" from the menu, saved it to my desktop and opened it with SketchUp. It looks like this.
lines.text_raw: After SketchUp, the .STL exporter and Pepakura have been installed it is time to try a simple model. I went to http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/ and chose "Geodesic dome 01" from the menu, saved it to my desktop and opened it with SketchUp. It looks like this.

lines.text: Begin by pulling down the Tools menu and clicking on Export to .DXF or .STL.
lines.text_raw: Begin by pulling down the '''Tools''' menu and clicking on '''Export to .DXF or .STL'''.

lines.text: The following menu will ask you whether or not you want the entire model exported; click Yes.
lines.text_raw: The following menu will ask you whether or not you want the entire model exported; click '''Yes'''.

lines.text: Click on any unit (Pepakura scales to page).
lines.text_raw: Click on any unit (Pepakura scales to page).

lines.text: On next box, click on .STL in drop-down menu. Continue.
lines.text_raw: On next box, click on '''.STL''' in drop-down menu. Continue.

lines.text: Save file where you can find it.
lines.text_raw: Save file where you can find it.

lines.text: Open Pepakura.
lines.text_raw: Open Pepakura.

lines.text: Once Pepakura is open pull down the File menu and click Open. Select the .STL file you just saved.
lines.text_raw: Once Pepakura is open pull down the '''File''' menu and click '''Open'''. Select the .STL file you just saved.

lines.text: Pepakura will ask you if you want to flip faces; click No (unless you do want to).
lines.text_raw: Pepakura will ask you if you want to flip faces; click '''No''' (unless you do want to).

lines.text: Pepakura will ask you which side is front and which side is top by face color. Choose correct colors and continue. It will ask you one last time to flip. Select No if correct and continue.
lines.text_raw: Pepakura will ask you which side is front and which side is top by face color. Choose correct colors and continue. It will ask you one last time to flip. Select '''No''' if correct and continue.

lines.text: Your page should now look like the image shown, with bottom of dome on ground.
lines.text_raw: Your page should now look like the image shown, with bottom of dome on ground.

lines.text: Now click on the Unfold box at top.
lines.text_raw: Now click on the '''Unfold''' box at top.

lines.text: Your dome is now "unfolded" !!
lines.text_raw: Your dome is now "unfolded" !!

lines.text: Go to 2D settings and increase scale several times until it fits the page.
lines.text_raw: Go to '''2D settings''' and increase scale several times until it fits  the page.

lines.text: Use the menus to rotate, adjust tabs, etc. until the dome is the way you want it.
lines.text_raw: Use the menus to rotate, adjust tabs, etc. until the dome is the way you want it.

lines.text: Print!
lines.text_raw: Print!

lines.text: Once the model is printed you need to cut it out.
lines.text_raw: Once the model is printed you need to cut it out.

lines.text: Dashed lines are fold lines and solid lines are cut lines.
lines.text_raw: Dashed lines are fold lines and solid lines are cut lines.

lines.text: All solid (cut) lines need to be cut, even if they seem to intersect other parts.
lines.text_raw: All solid (cut) lines need to be cut, even if they seem to intersect other parts.

lines.text: You may now fold and glue. Remember that the folds you make for the dome should be sharply creased but only bent slightly as the angles on the dome are slight. It will take practice to determine what is right.
lines.text_raw: You may now fold and glue. Remember that the folds you make for the dome should be sharply creased but only bent slightly as the angles on the dome are slight. It will take practice to determine what is right.

lines.text: You may also want to find or make a folding tool for small folds. I was able to use my fingers when folding the dome but this won't be possible on some other models.
lines.text_raw: You may also want to find or make a folding tool for small folds. I was able to use my fingers when folding the dome but this won't be possible on some other models.

lines.text: You can now take the knowledge you have gained and apply it to other things!
lines.text_raw: You can now take the knowledge you have gained and apply it to other things!

lines.text: You might try printing paper patterns, gluing them to sheet metal and screwing or welding the parts together.
lines.text_raw: You might try printing paper patterns, gluing them to sheet metal and screwing or welding the parts together.

lines.text: You might also try printing things and enlarging them with an opaque projector onto large sheets of vinyl, cloth or plywood to make larger objects.
lines.text_raw: You might also try printing things and enlarging them with an opaque projector onto large sheets of vinyl, cloth or plywood to make larger objects.

lines.text: The possibilities are endless!
lines.text_raw: The possibilities are endless!

guide.summary: Use SketchUp and Pepakura to create designs in paper, metal or plastic.
guide.title: Paper Items with SketchUp and Pepakura

tools.text: Computer running Windows XP, Vista, or Mac OS X
